awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Cyanobacterial enzymes and strains for removal of organophosphonates
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of low-cost sprayable, fast-acting enzymes/microorganisms that degrade organophosphonate into environmentally-friendly intermediates or final products, reducing envirionmental pollution from these agrochemicals. The increased use of phosphonates (as cleaning agents, coolants, and pesticides, etc.) is problemmatic due to their slow degradability and resultant  accumulation in the environment. The proposed technology seeks to selectively degrade organophosphonates including glyphosate herbicides.  The proposed project will support the development of strategies for safe and effective use of agrochemicals and household chemicals for various essential applications.

This I-Corps project is based on the productio of three phosphonatases by overexpressing them heterogously in fast-growing cyanobacterial strains. These enzymes can be used for the removal of phosphonate contaminants in soil and water systems. Thermophilic cyanobacteria species from Hot Springs, Arkansas are also identified as strains expressing these enzymes in high levels. This projects seeks use the novel mechanisms of organophosphonate degradation and to help clean the environment. Several cyanobacterial species may be able to survive on organophosphonate as the only source of phosphorus, breaking down organophosphonates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project aims to develop a low-cost sprayable fast-acting enzymes/microorganisms that break down agrochemicals containing carbon-phosphorus bond (such as glyphosate, the main ingredient of the herbicide Roundup) into environmentally friendly intermediate or final products, preventing agrochemical pollution of the environment.

The main outcomes:

We screened for cyanobacterial strains for their capability to grow in media containing organophosphate as the sole source of phosphorus, and we evaluated the suitability of the strains/enzymes for detoxification of Roundup.

We attended the Southwest I-Corps Node (Award# 1740705), and completed 32 interviews during the program and received their endorsement for the participation in the national I-Corps.

After receiving the I-Corps award, we completed I-Corps Course in Fall 2022 - Northeast cohort #1 (Oct 11 to Nov 22), interviewed more than 100 potential customers and influencers, and received the certificate of completion.

Based on what we learned from I-Coprs trainning, we pivoted our research and exploration to developing products for remediation of crops after accidental spray of herbicide on crops.

The grant supported one graduate student, Precious Richard, for one year. He learned a lot from the I-Corps courses and interviews. He will develp his dissertation project based on the learnings.

We presented our results at (1) the 2023 Meeting of Southern Section of the American Society of Plant Biologists at Fayetteville Arkansas, March 25-27, 2023; (2) UA Little Rock Student Research and Creative Works Expo, Apr 21, 2023; (3) 49th MSWE Photosynthesis Meeting at Turkey Run State Park, IN, October 27 to 29, 2023

During the no-cost extension period, we interviewed more potential customers and refined our products. We have requested reallocating $5,000 for MVP development and received approval from the program manager.

The customer interviews taught us that farmers were reluctant to adopt an extra soil cleaning step after application of Roundup unless government regulates and subsidizes the practice since the cleaning step adds extra cost. However, accidents such as mis-calculation or wind drift do happen from time to time, and under these circumstances they desire a product that can help cleaning up or quickly removing roundup residues. These require our strains to be able to tolerate much higher concentration of Roundup and be able to break it down rapidly. This needs further research.

We would like to emphasize on cyanobacterial strains that can also fix atmospheric nitrogen and adhere well to solid surfaces, this adds extra value (as nitrogen fertilizers) to the strains
